module.p: siud that (one) over there is a demonstrative pronoun, identifying an entity based on its spatial location distal to both the speaker and the hearer.
siud contrasts with seo this (one) (proximal to the speaker) and sin that (one) (proximal to the hearer).

section.p:
siud can be used as the subject of a verb –
Tha siud cudromach. That is important.

Pedagogical examples –
Tha siud dìreach àlainn.
That is just beautiful. td. 27

When siud is used as the subject of the copula is, the copula itself is usually dropped –
Is siud Dòmhnall. ⇒ Siud Dòmhnall. That is Donald.

Pedagogical examples –
Siud Iain.
Yon is John. td. 27

Examples with dummy subject pronouns –
with relaxed agreement–
Is e siud Anna.
That/yon is Ann. td. 27
negative examples –
Chan e siud an tidsear.
That is not the teacher. td. 27

siud can be used as the object of a verb –
Chunnaic mi siud a-rithist. I saw that (one) again.

Some examples –
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. “Fuirich gus an dùin mi i is gus an cuir mi seòladh oirre. Ceannaich fhéin stamp agus cuir oirre i.” Tha Iain a’ ruith sìos an rathad leis an litir ’na làimh. Théid e a steach do oifig a’ phuist, ceannaichidh e stamp is cuiridh e sud air an litir. [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” “Wait until I seal it and put an address on it. Buy a stamp and put it on it.” John is running down the road with the letter in his hand. He will go into the post office, he will buy a stamp and put that on the letter. [...] td. 5 implied subject in second example

siud can be used as the complement of a preposition –
Thàinig iad le siud. They came with that (one).

siud can be used as the specifier of a noun –
Tha mi a’ faicinn siud. I can see that (one).
Tha e ri taobh siud. It is beside that (one).

siud can serve as a modifier of the definite article, appearing after the specified noun and any attributive adjectives –
am balach beag siud that little boy
na craobhan àrda siud those tall trees (over there)

Pedagogical examples –
singular –
a’ bheinn ud | am baile ud
yon mountain | yon town td. 26, 195
plural –
na caileagan ud
yon girls td. 26

Examples from Gairm –
[...] Dh’fhàs a guth na bu làidir. “Tha aon rud cinnteach, chan fhalbh aon choigreach le mo leanabh. Cha teid i gu aon dannsa, tha sin cinnteach. Tha. Tha. Na bi smaoineachadh gun teid, a leanaibh. Chan eil fhios agad mu ’n deidhinn, mar a th’ agamsa.” “Carson nach do bhàsaich thu o chionn leth-cheud bliadhna,” dh’ éigh Màiri. Bha i smaoineachadh air na gnothaichean ud fhathast! “Greas ort leis an tea,” ars a màthair. [...]
[...] Her voice grew louder. “One thing is certain, not one stranger will leave [go out?] with my child. She will not go to a single dance, that is certain. It is. It is. Do not be thinking that you will, child. You don’t know about them, as I do.” “Why did you not die fifty years ago,” shouted Mary. She was still thinking about those matters! “Hurry up with the tea,” said her mother. [...] td. 171, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

siud can modify a third-person personal pronoun, thus yielding explicitly gendered or plural demonstratives –
e siud yon [masc.]
i siud yon [fem.]
iad siud those, yon

module.p: an siud over there, at that place over there is the demonstrative adverb derived from siud.

Pedagogical examples –
Tha an t-aran an siud.
The bread is yonder. td. 195
